H0.text: Life cycles are haploid-dominant in fungi such as black bread mold (rhizopus nigricans).

H1.text: Birth cycles are haploid-dominant in fungi such as black bread mold (Rhizopus nigricans).

H2.text: Gene pools are haploid-dominant in fungi, such as black bread mold (Rhizopus nigricans).

H3.text: Mutations are haploid-dominant in fungi such as black bread mold (Rhizopus nigricans).

A4.text: Sexual reproduction occurs when compatible haploid mating types in the form of hyphae make contact with each other, producing diploid zygospores.

A5.text: Meiosis is delayed until the germination of the zygospores.

A6.text: In sexual reproduction, a dark zygospore is produced at the point where two compatible mycelia fuse.

A7.text: Upon germination, a zygospore produces colonies that are genetically different from either parent.

A8.text: In the whole cycle, zygotes are the only diploid cell; mitosis occurs only in the haploid phase.

A9.text: In most diplonts, mitosis occurs only in the diploid phase, i.e. gametes usually form quickly and fuse to produce diploid zygotes.

A10.text: Most fungi have both a haploid and a diploid stage in their life cycles.
